verses.text: Now John went up from Gazara and told Simon, his father, what Cendebeus was doing.
verses.comment: Here John brings news of Cendebeus, showing the importance of vigilant leadership. The preservation of Israel often depended on sons bearing responsibility for their father's work, anticipating similar themes of succession and spiritual warfare as seen in 2 Tim. 2:2.

verses.text: Simon called his two older sons, Judas and John, and said to them: 'My brothers and I, and my father's house, have fought the battles of Israel from our youth to this day, and often we have succeeded in saving Israel.'
verses.comment: Simon’s speech highlights faithfulness through generations, similar to biblical calls for perseverance (Heb. 12:1). The continuity of leadership foreshadows the unity of the church passed from one generation to the next.

verses.text: 'But now I have grown old, and you, by God's mercy, are of mature age. Take my place and my brother’s, and go out and fight for our nation; and may the help that comes from heaven go with you.'
verses.comment: Simon entrusts leadership to his sons, relying on divine help. This is a key example of apostolic succession in leadership, where appointed leaders carry on the mission of their predecessors.

verses.text: Then he chose twenty thousand of the best soldiers and cavalry, and they set out for Cendebeus. They camped by Modin.
verses.comment: Simon’s selection of a strong force mirrors the notion of the church as a well-ordered body, advancing with discipline and unity (cf. 1 Cor 14:40).

verses.text: They set out at night and marched as far as the plain. Cendebeus was camped with his army at Kedron.
verses.comment: The element of a night march brings to mind biblical episodes of divine strategy (Josh 8:9-10).

verses.text: John placed his troops in ambush, while his brother went forward with the main force.
verses.comment: Ambush tactics echo Old Testament precedents for holy warfare, where strategy and obedience to God work together.

verses.text: When all Cendebeus’s men came out into the plain, the main army attacked, and many of them fell. The rest fled to the stronghold.
verses.comment: Victory is both a result of bravery and God’s providence, a recurring biblical theme (see Psalm 44:3).

verses.text: Judas, John’s brother, was wounded in the battle, but John pursued the enemy until he reached Kedron, which Cendebeus had fortified.
verses.comment: Even in victory, suffering among leaders reminds us that the righteous may endure tribulation for a greater cause—pointing to Christ’s suffering in salvation’s plan.

verses.text: Some of those who fled fell by the sword; the rest reached the fortified city.
verses.comment: The enemy’s flight recalls the ultimate futility of opposition to the chosen people, paralleling the church’s promise of victory over the gates of hell (Matt 16:18).

verses.text: They also fled into the towers that were in the fields of Azotus, and John burned them with fire, and about two thousand of them fell. He then returned to Judea safely.
verses.comment: John Hyrcanus' decisive action at Azotus illustrates the harsh realities of ancient warfare and reflects the struggle for Jewish autonomy against hostile neighbors, echoing earlier biblical accounts of purging enemy strongholds (cf. Joshua 10:28-39).

verses.text: Now Ptolemy, the son of Abubus, had been appointed governor in the plain of Jericho. He had much silver and gold,
verses.comment: Ptolemy’s position and wealth remind us of recurring biblical warnings on the dangers and temptations of power (1 Tim 6:10).

verses.text: for he was the high priest’s son-in-law.
verses.comment: This family tie shows how political and religious roles intertwined, anticipating the significance of spiritual authority entrusted to specific leaders.

verses.text: But his heart grew proud, and he plotted to seize leadership by treachery.
verses.comment: Ptolemy’s betrayal echoes figures such as Absalom (2 Sam 15), warning against rebellion against God’s chosen leaders. This scene encourages fidelity toward God’s established order.

verses.text: As Simon was making the rounds through the cities in the country, caring for their needs, he went down to Jericho—he and his sons, Mattathias and Judas, in the one hundred seventy-seventh year, in the eleventh month (which is the month Shebat).
verses.comment: Simon's pastoral care for the cities illustrates the shepherding role vested in spiritual leaders; this pattern would later be fulfilled by the Good Shepherd (John 10:11).
verses.sectionHeader: The Murder of Simon and His Sons

verses.text: The son of Abubus welcomed them with deceit in a little fortress called Dok that he had built. He spread a grand feast, but he had men hidden there.
verses.comment: This event parallels betrayals of trust in scripture (see Judas in Luke 22:48). The true leader faces betrayal as Christ did, reinforcing the cost of sacrificial leadership.

verses.text: When Simon and his sons became drunk, Ptolemy and his men rose up, took their weapons, and rushed upon Simon in the banquet hall, killing him and his two sons, and some of his servants.
verses.comment: The murder during a banquet underlines the depth of the betrayal. The connection to betrayal in the New Testament is striking, giving a foreshadowing of the ultimate sacrifice.

verses.text: So he committed an act of great treachery and returned evil for good.
verses.comment: Here, betrayal is sharply condemned, underlining the biblical theme of covenant faithfulness; the act serves as a warning against repaying good with evil, a principle taught in Proverbs 17:13.

verses.text: He wrote a report and sent it to the king, that he might send to his aid troops to give him the cities and the country.
verses.comment: Ptolemy’s alignment with foreign power for his own gain illustrates the dangers of depending on worldly authorities rather than trusting in the divine order.

verses.text: He sent other troops to Gazara to do away with John; he sent letters to the captains asking them to come to him so that he might give them silver and gold and gifts;
verses.comment: Ptolemy's secret plots—bribery and mobilization against John—reveal the treacherous political landscape of the period, emphasizing the perils of seeking security through alliances and gifts (see Psalm 12:2-3).

verses.text: and he sent other troops to take possession of Jerusalem and the temple hill.
verses.comment: The attempt to seize Jerusalem and the temple signifies a direct assault on Jewish identity and religious life, paralleling earlier threats to the sanctuary as seen in 1 Maccabees 1:21-24.

verses.text: But someone ran ahead and reported to John at Gazara that his father and brothers had perished, and that 'he has sent men to kill you also.'
verses.comment: Timely intelligence saves John, showing the importance of vigilance and crisis leadership; the report of familial loss underscores the personal cost of leadership, reminiscent of David's ordeals in 2 Samuel 15:13-16.

verses.text: When he heard this, he was greatly shocked; he seized the men who came to destroy him and killed them, for he had found out that they were seeking to destroy him.
verses.comment: John's swift retribution reflects both justified self-defense and decisive leadership in protecting the nation, while highlighting the theme of God's providence granting discernment and deliverance (cf. Psalm 18:48).

verses.text: The rest of the acts of John and his wars and the brave deeds that he did, and the building of the walls that he completed, and his achievements,
verses.comment: Communal mourning for righteous leaders is a sign of their true impact—symbolic of how loss is felt keenly among God’s people, much like the apostles grieved after the Lord’s Passion (Mark 16:10).

verses.text: are written in the annals of his high priesthood, from the time that he became high priest after his father.
verses.comment: The specific dating of these events strengthens the historical reliability of Scripture, and demonstrates God’s work in concrete times and places. The recording of dates for salvation history finds its fulfillment in the coming of Christ in the fullness of time (Gal 4:4).

sections.title: The Murder of Simon and His Sons
